title: snapshot not old enough yet: need 120 more blocks
body:
#### System information

Geth version: v1.10.3
OS & Version: Linux (dappnode)

#### Expected behaviour

pruning should work, snapshot age should increase

#### Actual behaviour

keeps reporting the same 'snapshot not old enough'

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

run `snapshot prune-state`


I don't really understand what you're doing. Is Geth printing this in a loop? Are you trying to run this over and over again? Are you doing anything in between?

Are snapshots generated already? Do you have some logs from Geth so we could see what blocks it's at? You seem to have run this command minute by minute, that's not gonna be enough to execute 120 more blocks? Did you start Geth in between to run some more blocks?

Yes, it's running in a loop. I'm running it via dappnode and it keeps trying to restart it with the same command.

Basically I've ran out of space about a month ago and stopped syncing, so I'm trying to prune state. It took about a week to generate the snapshots. 

> You seem to have run this command minute by minute, that's not gonna be enough to execute 120 more blocks?

Yes, but shouldn't it be executing some blocks and the number 120 decreasing? Clearly I don't know what's going on, but I'll try to start geth and see what happens. Problem is, I'm pretty much out of disk space.

Ok, the the first error was because the snapshots need to have a certain depth before you can use them to prune. That's why you needed to run Geth for a while, to pile a few more blocks on top.

Pruning does result in temporarily more space unfortunately. First we generate a 2GB bloom filter, which we need to store on disk (we prune based on this). And afterwards, deleting data from LevelDB is actually increasing it's size, until it gets to compact the junk out. That also happens at the end of the pruning only.

Bit of a tough nut to crack when you're already OOD. It honestly might be easier to delete your leveldb database (chaindata **without** the ancient folder within); and start a `snap` sync (`--syncmode=snap`). By keeping the ancients you will not need to download 200GB of blocks, only the latest state.

> Bit of a tough nut to crack when you're already OOD. It honestly might be easier to delete your leveldb database (chaindata without the ancient folder within); and start a snap sync (--syncmode=snap). By keeping the ancients you will not need to download 200GB of blocks, only the latest state.

Cool, I'll try it next time in such situation. For now I'm at the compacting database stage and have regained circa 200 gb already.
Glad you managed to fix it :)
